She said that she had worked to pull the resume out of the trash and un-crumple it. She could flatten it out to some degree. But try as she might, she couldn’t get it back to where it was before — the lines and creases from being crumpled and thrown away remained.

She asked the jury to imagine her,  a University of Richmond law professor, as a paper resume with all of her accomplishments listed. She then told the jury it felt like the landlord had just crumpled her up and tossed her aside once they found out she was Black.
To show the damage of discriminatory housing practices, I asked a client once to describe what it felt like to be turned down even though she later found a place. Here's what she said:
Often I would be arguing in front of majority-white or, sometimes, all-white juries, and I could see that they were thinking, “Yeah it was unfortunate—but you eventually found a place to live.”

One of the challenges I found in trying these cases was that, since most of my clients had found a home by the time of their trial, it was difficult for me to convince a jury that real damages had actually been inflicted.

Today I'm thinking of the lives lost at Pulse 3 years ago, and of every person in this country who's lost a loved one to gun violence. I'm thinking about how they must feel when we continue to simply stand by. We *can* reduce gun violence, and we owe it to them to take action.

But in 2016, I visited Pulse Nightclub in Orlando after 49 people lost their lives in another senseless mass shooting. And my fear that we wouldn’t learn from Virginia Tech and take action to prevent this kind of gun violence was affirmed. pic.twitter.com/AXBiBEdso3

I prayed that other people in other places wouldn’t have to grapple with such heartbreak. I knew that if it happened again, then it meant we hadn't learned anything. And that’s something I couldn’t, and still can’t, accept.

After the horrific shooting at Virginia Tech, I prayed that it would remain the worst mass shooting in our history. That’s a strange thing to say. But after experiencing something that painful, all I could hope was that it would be the last of its kind.

Please take a moment to join the Commonwealth of Virginia in mourning the deaths and celebrating the lives of these 12 people, and to reaffirm our shared responsibility to take action to prevent gun violence.

Robert “Bobby” Williams, a 41-year employee of the city of Virginia Beach Department of Public Utilities, was awarded with 8 service awards in recognition of his lifetime of devoted work. He was planning on retiring later in the year to spend more time with his family.
Herbert “Bert” Snelling was a contractor who had come to the Municipal Center to get a permit. He was celebrating his 38th wedding anniversary.
Christopher Kelly Rapp, an 11-month employee of the city of Virginia Beach Department of Public Works, was known for his kindness, his passion for playing the bagpipes, and his devotion to his wife.
Katherine A. Nixon was a 10-year employee of the city of Virginia Beach Department of Public Utilities who was known for her intellect. She was a loving wife and mother of 3 children.

Richard H. Nettleton was a 28-year employee of the city of Virginia Beach Department of Public Utilities, a selfless leader in regional utility system planning, and a veteran of the 130th Engineer Brigade of the Army.

Michelle “Missy” Langer was a 12-year employee of the city of Virginia Beach Department of Public Utilities who was known for her beaming smile and passion for the Pittsburgh Steelers. She had plans to retire soon.
Joshua O. Hardy was a 4-year employee of the city of Virginia Beach Department of Public Utilities who was known for his kindhearted nature and love for his family and faith.

Alexander Mikhail Gusev was a 9-year employee of the city of Virginia Beach Department of Public Works who emigrated from Belarus to Virginia Beach to find a better life. He was known as a generous and devoted coworker, friend, brother, and uncle.
Mary Louise Gayle was a 24-year employee of the city of Virginia Beach Department of Public Works who was known as a cheerful coworker and devoted mother and grandmother.
Tara Welch Gallagher was a 6-year employee of the city of Virginia Beach Department of Public Works. She worked as an engineer to provide clean drinking water for her community.

Ryan Keith Cox was a 12-year employee of the city of Virginia Beach Department of Public Utilities who was known for his kindness and beautiful singing voice. He ran into danger looking for more people to save after ensuring his coworkers were sheltered in a barricaded room.

Laquita C. Brown was a 4-year employee of the city of Virginia Beach Department of Public Works. She was known for her love of travel with friends and her ability to light up a room with her presence.

11 of the 12 victims were employees of the city of Virginia Beach with more than 150 years of combined service to the city, and the remaining victim was a contractor who had come to the Municipal Center for business.

Today @MarkWarner and I introduced a resolution honoring the 12 victims of the horrific shooting in Virginia Beach. As we mourn twelve beautiful lives, we want the country to know who these dedicated public servants, friends, and family members were. I hope you'll read this:
